hobby.message: Still folding origami to stay grounded?
Political literature still keeping you up?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: Rain seems unlikely tonight. Streets are unusually empty, though.
People have other priorities than weather, lately.
I collect old books, but it's been difficult with all the commotion.
Protests don’t encourage careful restoration work.
Dry enough for now, but you never know.
Things outside keep interrupting my hobby — banned political texts, mostly.
Harder to find a quiet hour when there’s shouting in every direction.
Some volumes got damaged with all the unrest.
Even preservation feels risky these days.
Clear skies, but volatile crowds — you can feel it in the air.
My hobby’s collecting and restoring banned political books.
Protests last night rattled a shelf, nearly tore the spine off an old manifesto.
Spent hours trying to fix a weathered pamphlet while the city boiled.
Restoring those texts takes steady hands. Lately, they shake.
The climate for collectors isn’t exactly hospitable now.
Still dry, yes, but the noise does more damage than rain ever could.
I spend evenings restoring banned books — politics, poetry, forbidden histories.
Last night’s riots nearly cost me a first-edition of Dissident Essays.
Usually, handling brittle pages is soothing. Not when the city’s in revolt.
One protestor’s megaphone quoted lines I’d memorized from the very books I hide.
Strange feeling: hearing your secret interests shouted by strangers outside.
Even keeping my collection feels like a protest itself now.
Dry, but every night feels like a storm lately — inside and out.
My real escape? Restoring blacklisted political texts, some centuries old.
Started the collection after my first compliance audit flagged a missing book.
It was Halden who showed me the trick to preserve acid-burned paper — before his loyalty slipped.
When the blackout erased half the city’s records, I lost track of cataloged editions for weeks.
During the riots, I hid a memoir under the floorboards as protestors marched past.
Sometimes I recognize phrases I restored in the slogans outside. Feels like a secret conversation.
Protecting those books is the closest I come to real dissent these days.
hobby_answer: Old books, yes. Some things never change.
Always have to be careful what I keep around.
After the leak, oversight's intense. Even reading feels suspect now.
Lost a favorite copy last week, had to hide it quick.
No sense tempting whatever watchers remain.
Still collecting, as quietly as I can.
You never know what gets flagged now, even phrases in margins.
The streets got loud after those erasures; my shelves got quieter.
A friend warned me some titles appeared on new lists.
Had to move half the collection out, just in case.
Strange, feeling less safe with words than ever before.
Yeah. Blacklisted books, annotated margins, the old thrill.
Seems bolder lately, though riskier; surveillance almost caught me sorting them.
The riots over those erased families... reminded me why I save these words.
People were quoting lines from my collection during the marches.
Had to stash everything deeper, lost an index card in the rush.
Feels like the system wants to erase the books too.
The city's panic is contagious—even pages feel dangerous now.
Always. Banned books outlast every regime, but lately it’s a closer call.
After the sabotage leak, the audits got sharper—I’ve had to scatter volumes.
I heard the crowd recite banned texts by my window.
I recognized some lines. Once, I’d fed them to leaders myself.
It’s odd—seeing samizdat go public again.
I lost track of what’s safe to even remember. Some books vanished with erased neighbors.
I make backups, but print carries a certain defiance.
Sometimes I wonder when my hobby crosses the line to something more.
I haven’t stopped. Smuggling banned words in my own phrases, copying texts by memory.
Yesterday, I heard protesters shouting passages from my oldest volume—ironic, since I wrote those speeches.
The erasures hit people on my street; the books feel heavier now.
After the data leak, one inspector searched my desk. I misdirected him to an official transcript, not the real stuff.
In truth, I hide catalog numbers in coded notes. Part necessity, part ritual.
When Marek died, I started preserving margins: personal annotations, little histories.
Sometimes I recite fragments from forbidden texts out loud, just to hear them survive.
My BCI score dropped after the leak, so finding new books is nearly impossible.
But even now, holding a banned text reminds me that the city's memory isn’t entirely algorithmic.
